arm_group.description: Oral fat diet contained 1487 kcal/m2 with 654 kcal/m2 (44%) as fat. In all cases, alcohol represented a daily total amount of 16 g/m2. The content of alcohol was 12% in red wine, 37% in rum, and 35% in brandy.Vodka was tri-distilled and contained 40% alcohol.

brief_summary.textblock:
Hypothesis: Red wine intake but not other alcoholic beverages  together with a fat diet will
      decrease inflammatory factors and lipid peroxidation and decrease antioxidant capacity in
      healthy people after a five days period.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Alcoholic Beverages in Pro-inflammatory and Antioxidant Profile After an Oral Fat Diet

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Healthy volunteers

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Individuals with a plasma cholesterol level > 220 mg/dl

          -  Smokers

clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Acute and Chronic Red Wine Intake in the Expression of Pro-inflammatory and Prothrombotic Factors in Circulating Monocytes

overall_official.affiliation: Head of section. Dep. of Internal Medicine

primary_outcome.measure: Change of baseline in concentrations of pro inflammatory factors and antioxidant capacity in plasma

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Instituto de Investigación Sanitaria Gregorio Marañón

clinical_study.source: Instituto de Investigación Sanitaria Gregorio Marañón

lead_sponsor.agency: Instituto de Investigación Sanitaria Gregorio Marañón

clinical_study.study_design: Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Basic Science
